title: Roger Federer strengthens his case as the 'GOAT'
text: Other Sports Roger Federer strengthens his case as the 'GOAT' Roger Federer sends a wake-up call to those who thought the 35-year-old legend was finished at the top of his sport Published 9:00 AM, January 30, 2017 Updated 9:00 AM, January 30, 2017 TIMELESS. With his Australian Open victory over Rafael Nadal, Roger Federer becomes the only man to win 5 titles in 3 different Grand Slams. Photo by William West/AFP MELBOURNE, Australia - Many people thought Roger Federer's Grand Slam-winning days were behind him, but he defied his age and conventional logic to seal his 18th major title at the Australian Open on Sunday, January 29. The Swiss master, returning from the longest injury break of his career, capped a resurgent fortnight with a 5-set victory over his long-time rival Rafael Nadal which extended his record haul of major singles titles. His latest Grand Slam win was perhaps his most surprising, as Federer last won a big title at Wimbledon in 2012 and at 35, his best days were considered over. But Federer beat Nadal 6-4, 3-6, 6-1, 3-6, 6-3 to become the second oldest major-winner in the post-1968 Open era, after Ken Rosewall won the 1972 Australian Open aged 37. It's an achievement which further strengthens Federer's case to be considered the greatest of all time, especially as he finally vanquished Nadal, his long-time nemesis. The victory made Federer the first man in history to win 5 or more titles at 3 different Grand Slam events: 5 in Melbourne, 7 at Wimbledon and 5 at the US Open. His fifth Australian Open triumph was thought improbable in the current era ruled by Murray and Novak Djokovic, before the top seeds' early exits opened the door to the title. Federer, who spent a record 302 weeks at number one and was inside the top 10 from 2002 until 2015, saw his ranking slide to 17 - his lowest since 2001 - after he spent 6 months out last year with a knee injury. The Swiss legend did not play a match from July after tumbling during the final set of a loss to Milos Raonic in the semi-finals at Wimbledon. Federer had had surgery for the first time in his career on his left knee in February and after the Wimbledon setback he did not finish the season, missing the US Open and the Rio Olympics. But he said the long period of rest fuelled his incredible charge at the Australian Open, where he overcame 3 top-10 players in Tomas Berdych, Kei Nishikori and Stan Wawrinka to reach a record 28th Grand Slam final. The result is that he stretches his lead on the all-time major-winners' list, 4 ahead of Nadal and Pete Sampras and 6 more than Djokovic. He holds the all-time men's record of 314 Grand Slam wins, and has career earnings of more than US$100 million.
